name: The Four Dragon Kings
subtitle: Lords of the Four Seas
description: The Four Dragon Kings are the divine rulers of the seas who control weather, rainfall, and all bodies of water in Chinese mythology. Dwelling in magnificent crystal palaces beneath the oceans, they command vast armies of aquatic creatures and serve under the authority of the Jade Emperor, regulating the waters that sustain all life.
sacredTreasures: Ruyi Jingu Bang (Sun Wukong's staff - originally a pillar in Ao Guang's palace)

fourKings.notes: Rules the warm southern waters and summer rains

dragonPalace.description: Each Dragon King rules from a magnificent Crystal Palace (ÈæôÂÆ´) beneath the sea, described as a wonder beyond mortal imagination.
architecture: Built from coral, crystal, and precious gems
Treasury with magical weapons, pearls, and cosmic artifacts

mythology_content.overview: The Dragon Kings feature prominently in Chinese mythology, literature, and folklore. Their stories explore themes of divine justice, natural order, and the relationship between heaven, earth, and water.

keyMyths.title: Nezha and the Dragon's Son
keyMyths.description: The young god Nezha bathed in the sea using his magical sash, which disturbed the Dragon Palace. When Ao Guang sent his third son Ao Bing to investigate, Nezha killed him in combat and skinned his tendons to make a belt for his father. This act brought the wrath of all four Dragon Kings.

keyMyths.title: Sun Wukong's Visit
keyMyths.description: In Journey to the West, the Monkey King descended to the Dragon Palace of the East Sea seeking a weapon. After testing and rejecting numerous weapons, he claimed the Ruyi Jingu Bang - a magical iron pillar that had been used to measure the depths of the Heavenly River. He also demanded golden chain mail, cloud-walking boots, and a phoenix-feather cap.

keyMyths.title: The White Dragon Horse
keyMyths.description: The third son of the Dragon King of the West Sea was condemned to death for burning the palace's pearl. Guanyin transformed him into a white horse to carry the monk Xuanzang on his journey to India, achieving redemption through service.

keyMyths.title: The Origin of Rain
keyMyths.description: The Dragon Kings are responsible for delivering rain according to the Jade Emperor's decrees. Each region of China has a designated dragon who must release the proper amount of rainfall. Stories abound of dragons who delivered too much or too little rain and faced celestial punishment.

keyMyths.title: The Dragon Gate
keyMyths.description: Carp that successfully leap over the Dragon Gate (ÈæôÈó®) at the Yellow River are transformed into dragons. This myth symbolizes success through perseverance, particularly in the imperial examination system.

sacredSites.name: Coastal Temples
sacredSites.description: Major shrines along China's coastline, especially in fishing communities

sacredSites.name: River Temples
sacredSites.description: Along the Yellow River, Yangtze, and other major waterways

sacredSites.name: Lake Shrines
sacredSites.description: At famous lakes like Dongting, Poyang, and Tai

sacredSites.name: Beijing Summer Palace
sacredSites.description: Dragon King Temple at Kunming Lake

sacredSites.name: Taiwan
sacredSites.description: Numerous Dragon King temples in fishing villages

festivals.date: Fifth day of the fifth lunar month
festivals.description: Dragon boat races honor the Dragon Kings and the poet Qu Yuan

festivals.name: Dragon Raising Head Day (ÈæôÊä¨Â§¥)
festivals.date: Second day of the second lunar month
festivals.description: Marks when dragons awaken from winter sleep and begin bringing spring rains

festivals.name: Rain Prayer Ceremonies
festivals.description: Performed during droughts with elaborate rituals

offerings: Paper boats (burned to send messages to the underwater realm)
Dragon effigies (paper dragons burned during drought ceremonies)
patronage: Fishermen and sailors seeking safe voyages
Those living near rivers and coastlines
Anyone whose livelihood depends on water

archetype.description: The Dragon Kings embody the Water Deity archetype - divine rulers of the seas who control weather, storms, and the life-giving rains essential to civilization.

sections.title: Overview
sections.content: The Four Dragon Kings are the divine rulers of the seas who control weather, rainfall, and all bodies of water in Chinese mythology. Dwelling in magnificent crystal palaces beneath the oceans, they command vast armies of aquatic creatures and serve under the authority of the Jade Emperor.
